document.docTitle: Hoplodrina kononenkoi Wu & Owada 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the Hoplodrina implacata group (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae: Noctuinae: Caradrinini) of Taiwan, with descriptions of four new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the Hoplodrina implacata group (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae: Noctuinae: Caradrinini) of Taiwan, with descriptions of four new species

Diagnosis. This new species shows its close affinity to
H. euryptera Boursin, 1937
( China , Japan , Korea ; figs 12, 23, 30) judging on the male genitalia. Externally there is no remarkable difference between them, in genitalia, and
H. kononenkoi
differs to
H. euryptera
by the more curved costal margin; the wider juxta; the less curved harpe rather than strongly curved; the two similar sized cornuti rather than one large and one small; the more granular corpus bursae.

Male genitalia ( Fig. 19 )—Uncus curved toward anterior part, apical part swollen with acute tip. Tegumen broad, peniculus well developed covered with long hair-like scales. Saccus tapered, V-shaped. Valva with costal and ventral margins slightly concave medially, respectively, subapical part of ventral margin protruded outwards; succulus elongated, harpe digitiform, slightly curved at apical part; cucullus extended, apex sharp; corona represented by 16 – 18 spines. Juxta plate-like, slightly concave at medial apical margin and extended as a small horn shape basally. Aedeagus about 4/5 length of valva. Carina with three sclerotized bands. Vesica with three diverticula, basal one membranous, other two medial ones covered with numerous spines. Tubular extension of vesica pointing posteriorly when fully swollen. Phallobase protruded anteriorly.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution and bionomics. Endemic to Taiwan . The species is distributed in mid-elevation broad-leaved forests of Taiwan . The adults occur from September to November. Comparatively the population is larger than other Taiwanese congeneric species.

Etymology. Named after Dr. Vladimir Kononenko (Valdivostok) who first reviewed the Eastern Palearctic and Oriental taxa of the genus
Hoplodrina
in 1997.
